data.title: Help > Check for updates appears as a no-op on Windows
data.body:
It used to be that clicking Help > Check for updates would check for updates and if no update is available would let me know via an info message that there are no available updates.

Today there is no feedback given after I click, i.e. I don't know if the action is broken or if there are no available updates.

data.title: Adopt templated tree renderer in references widget
data.body: Looks like `referencesWidget.ts` is the last client of [`LegacyRenderer`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/editor/contrib/referenceSearch/browser/referencesWidget.ts#L347) of the tree where we are not reusing DOM elements (aka templated rendering).

data.title: [Feature request] Add an option to display errors inline
data.body: # Issue At the moment, errors are underlined with a wavy red line: And you have 3 ways to see what the error is : 1. hover the line with the mouse 2. navigate the cursor to the error and hit ctrl+k and then ctrl+i 3. hit F8 until you navigate to the errors Those all work great but need some extra-work 1. You have to quit the keyboard 2. you have to navigate to the error, and then remember the 2 key shortcuts 3. if there are may errors, you might have to loop through a bunch of them before getting the one you're interested in Of course you also could have the "Errors" panel open, but again, if you have many errors the one you interested in might be buried below what's visible without scrolling. # Request It would be nice if there was an option to display errors next to the line containing those errors, so they'll show up without any user-interaction. Here's what it could look like : # Challenges - The line might be a long one, and the error message would then not be visible - In case there are multiple errors on a same line, how do you display it The errors could be displayed on the next line instead, but from what I saw inspecting the app, it might be tricky to do since the "decorators" are positioned absolutely beneath the actual line of code.

data.title: Support for .dist file language detection
data.body:
One pattern for distributing configuration files that can be overridden by the user is the use of `file.ext.dist` files. An example is the PHPUnit testing framework, which supports an `phpunit.xml.dist` file which can then optionally be overridden locally with a `phpunit.xml` file.

When I open a `.dist` file in VS Code, the language isn't detected (for example, VS Code doesn't treat `phpunit.xml.dist` as an XML file). Other editors such as Atom do support this, and it saves me from having to switch the Language Mode to XML each time I open the file.

It would be great if VS Code used the extension that appears before the `.dist` extension in the filename to determine the language.

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

data.title: AutoComplete enhancement: press enter on selecting suggestion.
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.12.2 (1.12.2) - OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Enter some words, like `toLowerCase`. 2. Suggestion will show up. If I press enter, and I have `acceptSuggestionOnEnter` enabled, `"editor.acceptSuggestionOnEnter": true,`. The current behavior is it will create a newline, but I think since we are selecting the suggestion, the correct behavior should be dismiss the suggestions ( which this is Sublime's default behavior).

data.title: Complete Emmet 2.0 support
data.body:
Contd. from #21943

Emmet Actions:

- [x]  Increment/Decrement by n
- [x]  Evaluate Math Expression
- [x] Toggle Comment
- [x] Multi cursor support for Wrap with abbreviation and Expand abbr commands #27621

Port current Emmet customizations to the new model:
- [x] `Emmet: Expand Abbreviation` command in languages that are not supported by emmet explicitly like php #28286
- [x] Port customization of [output profile](https://docs.emmet.io/customization/syntax-profiles/)
- [x]  Port customization of [variables](https://github.com/emmetio/emmet/blob/master/lib/snippets.json#L2-L8) in emmet snippet. In new emmet, this will be via a new setting `emmet.variables`
- [x] Port the use of `emmet.extensionsPath` for custom variables and profiles #28465
- [x] Port the use of `emmet.exlcudeLanguages`


Optimize Emmet expansions
- [x] Use right language in case of embedded language. For eg: <style> block in html should use css #28039
- [x]  Use regex to filter out invalid abbreviations. #27628 and #27975
- [x]  Dont provide emmet suggestion inside the html tag or inside css selectors #28829
- [x]  Use VS Code specific stream reader for more efficient html and css parser
- [x]  Enable language extensions to call emmet completion provider #29114

Others:
- [x] Add typings 

Deferred Emmet Actions:
-  Update Image Size (Pending resolution of https://github.com/emmetio/atom-plugin/issues/21)
-  Reflect CSS Value (No re-usable module from emmet yet. We should probably do this on our own)

data.title: Test TypeScript.npm Setting
data.body:
Test for #24961

**Complexity**: 2

**OS**
- [x] Linux @Tyriar 
- [x] Mac @bpasero 
- [x] Windows @michelkaporin 


## Background
Automatic typings acquisition uses npm to install type definition files. Currently we try to pick up npm from the PATH. There are a number of cases where we end up not being able to find a npm executable on the PATH

VScode 1.13 adds a new `typescript.npm` setting that you can use to  explicitly tell VSCode/TypeScript where npm is installed


## Prep
- Make sure npm is not on your PATH

  One option for this is to simple rename or move the npm executable. Try running `which npm` to see where your npm executable currently is

- Clear the typings cache

  This is located at `~/.cache/typescript/` on linux, `~/Library/caches/typescript` on mac and `%LOCALAPPDATA%\Microsoft\TypeScript` on windows: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40941447/where-are-automatic-type-acquisition-typescript-definition-files-saved

- Make sure you don't have other VSCode instances running that may try to repopulate the typings cache

- Test that npm cannot be found

  Boot up vscode. Create a new js file with the contents `const $ = require('jquery')`. You should see a warning  about missing npm. There should be no intellisense for jquery.  If you get intellisense on the jquery import, either npm is still on your path or the cache has not been cleared

## Testing
- Set `typescript.npm` to point to a valid npm executable somewhere on your system.
- Open a js file with some imports that are known to have typings, such as `const $ = require('jquery')`
- You should now see a message in the status bar about acquiring typings.
- Check that you get intellisense on the imports
- Try adding some other imports and ensure you get intellisense for those as well.
- Try changing `typescript.npm` to different values and triggering typings installs again

Also confirm that you cannot set `typescript.npm` in a workspace. It should only be allowed as a user setting

data.title: Cannot see entire task output in terminal in Linux
data.body: Testing #27471 On a fresh Ubuntu 16.04 * clone `https://github.com/Microsoft/node-native-keymap` * run `npm install .` * open the folder in VS Code * have node-gyp installed * create a non-syntactical error e.g. in `keyboard_x.cc` add `void f() { return x; }` * run build via `ctrl+shift+b` * show output => observe output in the Output window and errors getting picked up by the markers service * change the version of the `tasks.json` to `2.0.0` * restart VS Code * run build via `ctrl+shift+b` (bottom panel collapsed) * open terminal * observe you cannot scroll to see the task output with the mouse wheel or with a scrollbar (there is no scrollbar). This is different from running e.g. `ls -al` where the terminal gets a scrollbar: * e.g. of `ls -al` which has scrollbars:

data.title: Go to Matching Pair doesn't scroll the editor to the matched location
data.body:
Testing #27316 

- Create a long HTML file so that the matching pair of a tag is not in the view port
- Run the `Emmet: Go to Matching Pair` command 

When the setting `emmet.useNewEmmet` is `false`, the cursor goes to the matching pair, and window scrolls to show you the location

When the setting `emmet.useNewEmmet` is `true`, the cursor goes to the matching pair, but window does not scroll

Same thing happens when `Emmet: Go to next/prev edit point` and `Emmet: Select next/prev item` takes the cursor out of the viewport

The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
Testing #27471

From the limited amount of tasks I have migrated from 0.1.0 to 2.0.0, I changed the version in tasks.json and besides schema warning squiggles the tasks seem to execute fine.

Why is there a need for me to change this version?

Why is there a need for me to restart VS Code after changing this version?

What are the breaking changes I should be aware of?

Why can't VSCode migrate the tasks for me?

[Sorry if these questions seem obvious, but for me it is not clear]

data.title: Theming: Add scrollbar.background

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Have I missed it or is it missing? I would like to set the color of the scrollbar, but this doesn't seem to be implemented. The slider color is configurable, but not the scrollbar itself.

When I use Monokai Seti (i.e. black editor background) and position a black terminal window to the right of the editor there is no way to separate them visually. It would be great if the color of the scrollbar was configurable, or possibly a border outlining the complete VS Code app.

Link to the theme color reference for scroll bar:
https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/theme-color-reference#_scroll-bar-control

data.body: @chrmarti fyi for debt week

data.title: New shortcut for Start Without Debugging on macOS?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: 10.12.5

When click **Command + F5**, it enables VoiceOver instead of `Start Without Debugging`.
The reality is that on macOS you actually need click **Fn + Command + F5** which ususally needs two hands.

Maybe we can add an extra shortcut for macOS?

For example, **Command + R** for`Start Without Debugging`,
and **Command + D** for`Start Debugging`.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3375461/26617080/f43bb500-4587-11e7-8c60-eeab6f66677a.png)
